normalised: Telecommunications: Fiber to Home Expansion Gains Momentum in India

unnormalised: **Telecommunications: Fiber-to-Home Expansion Gains Momentum in India**
normalised: New Delhi – Reliance Jio and Bharti Airtel are aggressively expanding their Fiber to Home (F T T H) networks across India, aiming to connect millions of households with high speed internet. Doctor Rajesh Kumar, Telecom Regulatory Authority of India (T R A I) Chairman, emphasized the importance of robust F T T H infrastructure for achieving Digital India goals.

unnormalised: New Delhi – Reliance Jio and Bharti Airtel are aggressively expanding their Fiber-to-Home (FTTH) networks across India, aiming to connect millions of households with high-speed internet. Dr. Rajesh Kumar, Telecom Regulatory Authority of India (TRAI) Chairman, emphasized the importance of robust FTTH infrastructure for achieving Digital India goals.
normalised: Recent reports indicate significant progress in Tier two and Tier three cities like Jaipur and Lucknow, with both companies laying hundreds of kilometer of optical fiber cable. Airtel announced connecting over fifty thousand new homes in the last quarter alone. Jio is focusing on bundling F T T H services with its Jio T V and smart home solutions, offering subscribers access to four hundred plus T V channels and integrated security features.

unnormalised: Recent reports indicate significant progress in Tier-II and Tier-III cities like Jaipur and Lucknow, with both companies laying hundreds of km of optical fiber cable. Airtel announced connecting over 50,000 new homes in the last quarter alone. Jio is focusing on bundling FTTH services with its JioTV and smart home solutions, offering subscribers access to 400+ TV channels and integrated security features.
normalised: The expansion aims to cater to the growing demand for data intensive applications, including online education, streaming, and work from home arrangements. Real estate developers in Mumbai are increasingly incorporating F T T H connectivity as a standard amenity in new residential projects, boosting property value by an estimated rupee two hundred per square foot. The initiative promises to bridge the digital divide and enhance connectivity for both urban and rural communities, facilitating access to government services and opportunities for economic growth.

unnormalised: The expansion aims to cater to the growing demand for data-intensive applications, including online education, streaming, and work-from-home arrangements. Real estate developers in Mumbai are increasingly incorporating FTTH connectivity as a standard amenity in new residential projects, boosting property value by an estimated Rs. 200 per sq ft. The initiative promises to bridge the digital divide and enhance connectivity for both urban and rural communities, facilitating access to government services and opportunities for economic growth.
